newsitem.title: USA: Finger leads police to carjack suspect.
newsitem.headline: Finger leads police to carjack suspect.

text.p: Police often use fingerprints to nab criminals; this time they had the whole finger to lead them to a suspected carjacker.
Police say the suspect, Victor Arreola, allegedly stopped a van in National City, north of San Diego, and ordered out the driver, Emmanuel Balbuena, his wife and three children.
But when Arreola tried to get into the van on the driver's side, Balbuena, still in his seat, slammed the door, severing the middle finger on the suspect's right hand.
After contacting several hospital emergency rooms, police were told a patient had checked into Scripps Hospital in Chula Vista claiming he lost a finger in a motorcycle accident.
Prosecutor Patrick Espinoza on Friday picked up the story.
"They had a conversation with Mr. Arreola and brought the finger with them. One of the officers said, 'I think I have something for you.'

"'Yeah, that's my finger,' he (Arreola) said. The doctors were ready to reattach it, then the officers said, 'You're under arrest for carjacking.' That's when he changed his mind and said, 'That's not my finger.'"
It didn't matter. According to Espinoza, Balbuena showed up later and "fingered him there at the hospital" following the incident last month.
According to Friday's San Diego Union-Tribune newspaper, too much time had passed for the finger to be reattached.
Arreola is in jail awaiting a Jan. 9 trial on five counts of attempted carjacking and five counts of attempted robbery.
And the finger is in a refrigerator at National City police headquarters.
